items.title: Possible GPL violoation - iOS version of Dexed
items.body:
Hey so I saw that someone released an iOS version of dexed. Seeing that the original is licensed under the GPLv3 and that the App Store is not compatible with it I thought I'd reach out and let you know.

http://www.georgerosar.com/dexed/
https://apps.apple.com/app/id1462551596?ign-mpt=uo%3D8

items.title: GUI breaks audio in Ardour with realtime priority
items.body:
If Ardours audio engine is allowed to run with realtime priority, opening the Dexed GUI causes a massive wave of buffer underruns. This state even prevail after closing the GUI again, and requires an Ardour restart to recover.

Drastically increased ALSA buffers (eg. 44ms instead of 11ms)  mitgate this problem, but this renderes realtime scheduling useless and leads to unacceptable latency.

Revoking the realtime priority remedies this problem (but requires 22ms latency on my system for reliable audio). 

My guess is that some GUI related operations accidentally take place in Dexed's audio processing loop that would be called by Ardours realtime DSP thread.  Can anybody confirm this?

items.title: typo in header
items.body:
"DX7 FM multi plaform/multi format plugin"
should read: "DX7 FM multi platform/multi format plugin"

items.title: Workaround for crash initializing the ALSA client
items.body:
#132
works around the null pointer error.

items.title: Add MIDI portamento
items.body:
I saw the TODO item on portamento, and I implemented something.

It has a formula based on measurements I did quite long ago on Yamaha SY77 portamento delays.
DX7 may or may not have used identical values. I don't know DX7, this should be checked.

It's the kind of operation obtained when portamento is configured in poly mode.
It implements the CC 5 and 65.

items.title: UI upgrade status
items.body:
Hi @asb2m10, is there any update regarding the UI redesign?
I love the effort that has been put to put together dexed, and would like to offer my help –if needed– for the UI upgrade, being an interaction designer. I often felt there could be a couple of improvements that would definitely improve the UX and general usability of the plugin, and I would be interested to understand your vision for the UI redesign! Let me know if I can support somehow or even just give an external opinion.

items.title: Add option to keep keyboard focussed on the MIDI keyboard
items.body:
While browsing through patches and carts, I figured it would be very convenient for the computer keyboard to remain focussed on the on-screen MIDI keyboard component so that I could play notes as I clicked through patches. So I've added this functionality, as well as a toggle to configure it on and off. It was mostly for myself, but I figured that others might find it useful too!

Please let me know if you require any changes!

![DexedParameterDialog](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7825549/58386675-78b69680-8003-11e9-9bb7-760699b19e05.png)

items.title: Can't send / receive Sysex on Ardour
items.body:
If Dexed is used as Ardour plugin, it does not send patch data to the MIDI interface, nor does it receive incoming Sysex from MIDI devices. The Ardour track and plugin is correctly configured to use the hardware MIDI interface. 

Is this by design, a bug, or Ardours flaw?

items.title: Dexed crashes when changing ALSA MIDI inputs
items.body:
I usually use the Dexed standalone on manjaro linux (xfce). Using it as a plugin with Ardour seems to be utterly impossible as it will crash randomly when used with other plugins. In that case I don't even know whether the fault lies with Ardour or Dexed.
To get to the main point, the Dexed standalone crashes when I enable or disable MIDI channels in the options menu. In my case, I have set up 16 ALSA MIDI through ports. I use several instances of Dexed for different instrument parts so each instance needs to receive on a different MIDI through port. However, when enabling and disabling ports, Dexed frequently crashes, or simply ignores the settings and listens on ports it shouldn't be listening on while ignoring the relevant ones.

Sorry for sounding a bit annoyed, but the constant crashes are super frustrating if they continue to get in the way when trying to make music.

items.title: Patch loads from cart don't persist between song stop/starts
items.body: In Logic 10.3.2 on OS X Mojave, no matter what patch I load from a .syx cart, the preset reverts back to "Factory Preset 31 'Take Off'" whenever I stop/start the track.  How can I get the cart setting to save and persist between song stop/starts?

items.title: No MIDI output device on linux (using btwig) [SOLVED]
items.body:
![Screenshot from 2019-03-11 12-09-25](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/114097/54123038-9148e480-43f6-11e9-8c54-240fab6c0127.png)


The solution, for me, was to **use the standalone version of Dexed**, which picked up all my midi devices, and I can now successfully re-patch my VolcaFM (which is FANTASTIC thank you everyone who has worked on dexed, and especially for Linux support!).

Why am I leaving this here? Documentation. Also, when I forget how to do this in a year and search the issues, I save myself some time. (Hi future @0atman, hope you are well. Sorry I'm spending your retirement money on synths.)

<3

items.title: MPE support
items.body:
Just leaving this here for any good soul who would like to try their hands at it.

From Wikipedia:

> MIDI Polyphonic Expression (MPE) is a method of using MIDI that enables pitch bend, and other dimensions of expressive control, to be adjusted continuously for individual notes. MPE works by assigning each note to its own MIDI channel so that particular messages can be applied to each note individually.
>
> Instruments like the Continuum Fingerboard, Linnstrument, ROLI Seaboard, and Eigenharp let users control pitch, timbre, and other nuances for individual notes within chords. A growing number of soft synths and effects are also compatible with MPE, as well as a few hardware synths.

Here is [Roger Linn's explanation](http://www.rogerlinndesign.com/mpe.html) on why MPE was needed.

Here is the [MIDI Association's article](https://www.midi.org/articles-old/midi-polyphonic-expression-mpe) with a link to the ***technical specification*** (free registration required to download it.) The specification goes to great lengths to describe zones, master channels, and other concepts, so I think it's an essential resource for anybody interested in implementing this.

I'm thinking about getting one of these fancy new controllers and I'd love to use Dexed with it. Unfortunately, I did some tests in Bitwig and I couldn't get per-note pitch bend to work, no matter how I set up the MIDI channels or MPE settings. It's probably something that needs to be addressed in Dexed's code.

items.title: Program names are not available until editor is opened
items.body:
Hi,

it seems that the program names aren't loaded until the plugin editor is opened. I noticed this problem when attempting to reproduce a bug in [PresetMagician](https://presetmagician.com/) and noticed that all program names were empty.

I then used [mrswatson](https://github.com/teragonaudio/MrsWatson/) to ensure it's not a problem with my VST host implementation, and it seems it's not. Outpout of mrswatson (stripped to show only the program names):

```
- 00000000 000969 Programs (32 total):
- 00000000 000985   0: ''
- 00000000 000985   1: ''
- 00000000 000985   2: ''
- 00000000 001000   3: ''
- 00000000 001000   4: ''
- 00000000 001000   5: ''
- 00000000 001000   6: ''
- 00000000 001016   7: ''
- 00000000 001016   8: ''
- 00000000 001016   9: ''
- 00000000 001016   10: ''
- 00000000 001016   11: ''
- 00000000 001031   12: ''
- 00000000 001031   13: ''
- 00000000 001031   14: ''
- 00000000 001047   15: ''
- 00000000 001047   16: ''
- 00000000 001063   17: ''
- 00000000 001063   18: ''
- 00000000 001063   19: ''
- 00000000 001063   20: ''
- 00000000 001063   21: ''
- 00000000 001078   22: ''
- 00000000 001078   23: ''
- 00000000 001078   24: ''
- 00000000 001078   25: ''
- 00000000 001094   26: ''
- 00000000 001094   27: ''
- 00000000 001094   28: ''
- 00000000 001094   29: ''
- 00000000 001110   30: ''
- 00000000 001110   31: ''
- 00000000 001110 Current program: ''
```

Being not familar with Juce and it's calling sequences, I would assume that [createPluginFilter](https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed/blob/73a266dd70e58e7def14a52bf2a53b5486d083dc/Source/PluginProcessor.cpp#L290) would be called during loading of the plugin, so it's puzzling why the program names are not initialized - however, my assumption could be wrong.

I might try to build a debug version which includes logging at a later point it time, but that's all I can report for now.

items.title: Ardour can't save anymore the project after opening the GUI of Dexed
items.body:
Hello,

I have a weird problem with Dexed and Ardour 5.12 under Ubuntu. The problem concerns both the LV2 and VST versions. The symptom is the following : I can instantiate Dexed and play it, but if I open its GUI to edit whatever parameter, then Ardour cannot anymore save the project (Ctrl+S or from the menu), and there is no error message in the console ! I didn't found any workaround, even removing Dexed from the track is not enough to restore this function. When you quit Ardour, it asks you if you want to save or just quit, if you choose to save it tells you that Ardour was not able to save the project.     

I have this problem with a current project of mine, but I was not able however to reproduce it straightaway with a blank project. All the other VST and LV2 synths I have work fine in my current project, so I am little bit puzzled.

items.title: Support for 4-op style operators (YM2151)
items.body:
It would be great if Dexed could be used to load and create 4-op patches accurately; even better if it could be used with a DX21 or DX11 directly (same as DX7). I see DX21 sysex import in the TODO of README. There's a DXconvert program for that, and unless there's some real magic tricks, it'd just be an approximation.

Rather than convert the sysex, why not a 4-op edit mode? Add in the TX81Z waveforms. That way, we get the lo-fi 4-op feel, with the added modulation capabilities of TX81Z, which would be awesome! :) And sounds from the arcade/games (YM2151, YM2612/YM2608) would sound closer to the real thing with a 4-op engine, since they use similar internals (YM2164 uses the same pinout and memory map as YM2151 which has tons of documentation/code).

What are your thoughts? I don't think it'd be too hard since they are just a slightly simplified version of DX7's FM engine. The parameters layout would have to change. The only thing that makes the keyboards unique from the Arcades is the firmware which controls 'voice parameters', keyboard scaling/velocity sensitivity, pitch envelope generator. All of that extra stuff is already handled in Dexed.

Also, the 4-op algorithm list are the same used in the Yamaha DX9, which are a subset of DX7 algorithms with operators 1 and 2 disabled. :) 

Does this have a place in Dexed, maybe a pull request if you're not up to it?

items.title: Send large sysex by chunks to bypass faulty midi interface drivers
items.body:
Hi,

'Send current sysex cartridge to DX7' is not working on Linux.
It works on Windows.  Maybe someone can also test on Mac.

 With my testing it seems that Linux is having a hard time sending a large single buffer of 4104 bytes.

Recieving a cartridge from the DX7 to Dexed works fine. Single voices send ok also.

 I did a test with KMidimon to monitor the midi through connector on the DX7 as Dexed tries to send a cartridge.
This loopback test showed that only 3840 bytes looped back.
So the Linux system is not transmitting the full 4104 bytes.

![midi_through_sysex_capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18003792/43873787-1802baae-9b56-11e8-9723-eb1cb0ec3728.png)



 If I capture a cartridge from the DX7 using KMidimon, it shows that Linux seems to be splitting the 4104 sysex into 256 byte buffers.
I can then use KMidimon to play back this capture to the DX7 and it successfully transfers the sysex cartridge to the DX7.

![cartridge_sysex_capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18003792/43873789-1df78ad4-9b56-11e8-9605-3243f1d270e5.png)


So a possible solution would be if Dexed can send the cartridge in 2 or more smaller buffers, rather than one large one. 


I am using the Roland UM-ONE MK2, and I also tried with a generic usb midi interface.

items.title: Not differentiating between 'EDIT' and 'FUNCTION' sysex parameter changes
items.body:
Hi,

Dexed is not differentiating between the 'EDIT' and 'FUNCTION' sysex parameter changes that it recieves from the DX7. 

e.g.
pressing FUNCTION 2 (poly/mono) on the DX7 will cause dexed to change its OP3 EG Rate 2 to zero. 
Similar errors occur when pressing other function buttons.

The sysex look similar except for the fourth byte.
FUNCTION 2 =  f0 43 10 **08** 40 00 f7 
OP3 EG Rate2 = f0 43 10 **00** 40 00 f7

Dexed would need to look at the fourth byte of the sysex to differentiate that it is recieving an EDIT parameter, and not a FUNCTION parameter.

DX7 EDIT parameters 1-15, 30-32 have 01 as the fourth sysex value
DX7 EDIT parameters 16-29 have 00 as the fourth sysex value
DX7 function parameters 2-7, 17-32 have 08 as the fourth sysex value



btw, a handy app for viewing the incoming sysex on linux is 'KMidimon'

items.title: Please compile for 64 bits
Note-off or all-notes-off appears to be ignored
items.body:
Hello.

I notice in the changelog that there have been some recent changes to how `all-notes-off` MIDI events are handled. It seems that something is still not working correctly (I don't know if it worked correctly prior to those changes).

If I do the following:

1. Start up [Rosegarden](https://rosegardenmusic.com/).
2. Start up [Carla](https://github.com/falkTX/Carla/).
3. Create a new `Dexed.so` VST instance in Carla. Select a patch that will play a sustained note for as long as a key is held.
4. Create a MIDI track in Rosegarden and connect the MIDI output of Rosegarden to the `events` input of Dexed.
4. Write some long notes on the MIDI track. Press play and then stop playback in the middle of one of those long notes (so that `note-off` isn't reached).

At this point, Dexed will sustain the last note that it received forever. There appears to be no way to shut it up aside from manually toggling the MONO switch on and off on the synth.

I don't think Rosegarden is to blame here, as I've used the various MIDI inspector plugins in Carla to verify that Rosegarden is sending `all-notes-off` events on all channels.

This is actually a serious usability issue, as every time you happen to stop playback in the middle of a note, you then have to go into all of your Dexed instances and toggle the MONO switch to stop them blaring at you.

I'm on Arch Linux. Dexed is compiled from the latest git master (`73a266dd70e58e7def14a52bf2a53b5486d083dc`).

items.title: macOS Dexed standalone plays back with bizarre frozen flanger quality
items.body: I'm on macOS 10.13.5 using Dexed 0.9.4. When I load Dexed in Logic Pro X, everything sounds great. When I load Dexed in Hosting AU <https://ju-x.com/hostingau.html> or use the standalone version, the same patches play back as if they're run through a flanger, and Dexed will "stick" a bit on one note, so that the whole played chord does not play back. It's really odd. I've experimented with different bit depth, rate, and buffer size settings, and I have not found a fix.

items.title: Segmentation fault on Linux (VST, Carla, JACK/ALSA midi bridge)
items.body:
Hello!

When running Dexed as a VST plugin on Linux, the plugin crashes when clicking the `PARM` button to adjust settings. Running in Carla under `gdb` gives this backtrace:

```
(gdb) bt 10
#0  0x00007fffef9ac0db in juce::(anonymous namespace)::AlsaClient::AlsaClient (this=0x7fffe80ecd50)
    at ../../JuceLibraryCode/modules/juce_audio_devices/native/juce_linux_Midi.cpp:279
#1  0x00007fffef9abbff in juce::(anonymous namespace)::AlsaClient::getInstance ()
    at ../../JuceLibraryCode/modules/juce_audio_devices/native/juce_linux_Midi.cpp:205
#2  0x00007fffef9ac9ff in juce::(anonymous namespace)::iterateMidiDevices (forInput=true, deviceNamesFound=..., deviceIndexToOpen=-1)
    at ../../JuceLibraryCode/modules/juce_audio_devices/native/juce_linux_Midi.cpp:421
#3  0x00007fffef9ad21a in juce::MidiInput::getDevices ()
    at ../../JuceLibraryCode/modules/juce_audio_devices/native/juce_linux_Midi.cpp:553
#4  0x00007fffef9d11c6 in ParamDialog::ParamDialog (this=0x7fffe7df9e80) at ../../Source/ParamDialog.cpp:165
#5  0x00007fffef9c7d41 in DexedAudioProcessorEditor::parmShow (this=0x5555559184a0) at ../../Source/PluginEditor.cpp:160
#6  0x00007fffef9e574c in GlobalEditor::buttonClicked (this=0x555555919558, buttonThatWasClicked=0x55555595e430)
    at ../../Source/GlobalEditor.cpp:539
#7  0x00007fffef7fe26f in juce::Button::<lambda(juce::Button::Listener&)>::operator()(juce::Button::Listener &) const (
    __closure=0x7fffe7dfa5a0, l=...) at ../../JuceLibraryCode/modules/juce_gui_basics/buttons/juce_Button.cpp:397
#8  0x00007fffef899a82 in juce::ListenerList<juce::Button::Listener, juce::Array<juce::Button::Listener*, juce::DummyCriticalSection, 0> >::callChecked<juce::Button::sendClickMessage(const juce::ModifierKeys&)::<lambda(juce::Button::Listener&)>, juce::Component::BailOutChecker>(const juce::Component::BailOutChecker &, juce::Button::<lambda(juce::Button::Listener&)> &&) (this=0x55555595e578, 
    bailOutChecker=..., callback=...) at ../../JuceLibraryCode/modules/juce_core/containers/juce_ListenerList.h:145
#9  0x00007fffef7fe372 in juce::Button::sendClickMessage (this=0x55555595e430, modifiers=...)
    at ../../JuceLibraryCode/modules/juce_gui_basics/buttons/juce_Button.cpp:397

```

```
(gdb) list
274	    {
275	        jassert (instance == nullptr);
276	
277	        snd_seq_open (&handle, "default", SND_SEQ_OPEN_DUPLEX, 0);
278	        snd_seq_nonblock (handle, SND_SEQ_NONBLOCK);

281

283	        ports.ensureStorageAllocated (32);
```

Poking at `handle` doesn't show very much. The JACK server logs don't show anything interesting either. Enabling/disabling the JACK ←→ ALSA bridge doesn't seem to have any effect.

Is there some way I can get more useful information?

items.title: Parm Function Controls are not real time
items.body:
Adjusting controls on the PARM panel only takes effect when you hit OK. 
1) Bring up Patch 7 on CARTF0/CART2B.SYX Which is SYN-CLAV 3.
2) On the PARM Page turn on EG BIAS for the Wheel and Change the Value to 99
3) Hit Low notes with PARM page up and adjust the Mod Wheel while listening
4) Hit OK to Dismiss PARM page and repeat step 3.

I think this is real time on the original DX7, but mine is acting up and won't play longer than half a second.

* Upgrade to latest JUCE

items.body:
I know this is an esoteric need, but it would be nice for Dexed to respond to DUMP REQUEST, at least for for "1 voice data" (a single patch).  The DX7 has no such sysex I believe, but the TX816 definitely does.

This would allow Dexed to work better with various DX7 patch editors, such as Edisyn, which have a number of exploratory patch capabilities that Dexed doesn't have on its own.  It would also let Dexed work better with librarian tools.  And it's a very simple sysex string.

While I have you: I am confused why the sysex input device is under the Options button, but the sysex output device is under the PARM button.

items.title: Use Shift for fine tuning
items.body:
Its a niggly thing but I've seen it used on a few other software synths and it is especially useful on Breakpoint, which is probably the least used parameter on the system. When you are getting close to your desired value, holding down shift allows you to move the mouse without overshooting. It would make putting in patches out of books a little easier. 
Gosh, I bet I still have that book that gave you all the parts and patches to do a song. I did Drive by the cars but found patches that were better than the book. Chariots of Fire was in there too.

items.title: Velocity Scaling
items.body:
Perhaps I am missing something but, could there be a setting to scale down incoming MIDI velocity to a max of 110 from  the actual max of 128? My controller keyboard is playing over bright and loud. The original DX7 did not send or internally play velocities over 110. If we had a switch in the Controls Editor, that would work great!
Thanks.

Rick

items.title: Envelope Generator  in Water Droplets
items.body:
Water Droplets in in CART2B is an odd patch but it doesn't seem to work in your implementation. The original DX7 will play each operators second-rate/envelope at different times because the first rate is set to varying slow rates. While it is puzzling that this happens when you see a rate of 5 going to level 0 from level 0, it can be delightful to get a sudden change or addition to the sound seconds after your keypress down and although Yamaha thought of this, their implementation is also buggy. On the  original DX7, you will get a correct version or a condensed version. This seems to be related to how many of the previous 16 notes were held down to play past Rate/Level 2. Notes held long enough will play normal  and the others will play a faster condensed version. Your version is mathematically correct in that a rate of 5 will still take 0 milliseconds going from Levels 0 to 0, but it takes the fun out of it. The Yamaha implementation meant that it was unpredictable so it wasn't used much by programmers but your implementation could. 
I'm afraid my DX7 with E! got hit with a power surge and is now only capable of sending MIDI or I'd attach an audio file.
I'd like to suggest that a zero level change still take 10 ms per level. Perhaps the times could be altered logarithmically. If you are checking your DX7 results remember to first hold down 16 keys for about 15 seconds after which you will hear what it is supposed to sound like. 
Rick

items.title: Poly aftertouch interpreted as pitch bend
items.body:
Hello,

I've just noticed this issue in Reaper 64-bit: poly aftertouch messages are interpreted as pitch bend messages.

items.title: Sysex messages force pitch bend messages
items.body:
Using High Sierra.
If there are any **_Yamaha_** USB keyboards or synths plugged in and active, Dexed 0.9.4 a sound short tone will sound after Key Off or  will generate a continuous tone depending on which host is used. This happens when using any midi source including Dexed Keyboard.
It affects hosts Reaper, AU Lab, Hosting AU using Yamaha KX25, moXF6, moXF and likely others.
It does affect the Dexed stand alone application.
Sometimes changing clock / synch settings on keyboard can help.

NO issues when Midi is restricted to M Audio or other Midi inputs when Yamaha is off or disabled or unpluged.
Tested on 3 different machines. Several Yamaha boards.
DID NOT occur with 0.9.3 version.

Issue Does **NOT** affect Garage Band 10.2.0 or 6.0.5
Issue Does **NOT** affect Live Professor.

It **DOES** affect the Dexed stand alone application.
It **DOES** affect Reaper 5.78
It **DOES** affect AU Lab 2.3
It **DOES** affect Hosting AU 1.5.0

Work around - do not use Yamaha equipment.
No other issues detected.
Other than that - Great job, especially the EG Timing.
Thanks and cheers.
Peter Walker

Hi,

items.title: VST plugin segfaults on loading on Linux
items.body:
Tested with:

    /usr/lib/carla/carla-bridge-native vst /usr/lib/vst/Dexed.so Dexed

which gives a segmentation fault. Also Carla and Tracktion report the plugin as non-functioning when scanning for VST plugins. The standalone version works fine.

I compiled version 0.9.3 and this was still ok, so I did a `git bisect` to find the first bad commit. I used the following script for testing, whether a particular commit was working:

```
#!/bin/bash

# use VST headers installed under /usr/include/vst36
sed -i -e 's|public.sdk/source/vst2.x|vst36|g' \
    JuceLibraryCode/modules/juce_audio_plugin_client/VST/juce_VST_Wrapper.cpp

# compile
cd Builds/Linux
rm -rf build

export CXXFLAGS="${CXXFLAGS} -DHAVE_LROUND"
make CONFIG=Release || exit 125

# test
if [ -e build/Dexed.so ]; then
    /usr/lib/carla/carla-bridge-native vst build/Dexed.so Dexed || exit 2
    exit 0
else
    exit 125
fi

exit 1
```

I saved this script in the directory above the git checkout. Then I did:

    git bisect start a08cc255e92bb49b48ece54a131ea9014997ffc6 9d96a1580ea2ac6495e22bfc247ff9b72232a56
    git bisect run ../test.sh

The result is:

```
$ git bisect log
# bad: [a08cc255e92bb49b48ece54a131ea9014997ffc6] Force to use only gcc-7 for Travsi CI
# good: [9d96a1580ea2ac6495e22bfc247ff9b72232a56c] Version 0.9.3
git bisect start 'a08cc255e92bb49b48ece54a131ea9014997ffc6' '9d96a1580ea2ac6495e22bfc247ff9b72232a56c'
# bad: [2e15a57e9351656c712389ab40d41cb7a1304311] Icon update and midi learn startup fix
git bisect bad 2e15a57e9351656c712389ab40d41cb7a1304311
# bad: [2875e92f3b06ea0342df894f3933cdfacd615972] eliminate JUCE memory leak messages at shutdown
git bisect bad 2875e92f3b06ea0342df894f3933cdfacd615972
# skip: [532bec2926e325d27ab2378b2ba05be3f4afdf5b] Fixes incoherent header definition with implementation #109
git bisect skip 532bec2926e325d27ab2378b2ba05be3f4afdf5b
# skip: [6774ab729d2197334822f5669fadf10617ebd745] Fix #110, correct implementation of midi cc 120/123
git bisect skip 6774ab729d2197334822f5669fadf10617ebd745
# bad: [1c2974daba1da26550c44a5486384a71b65021ad] FIX #99  : the option "send current program to DX7" now sends the selected midi channel for sysex
git bisect bad 1c2974daba1da26550c44a5486384a71b65021ad
# skip: [4ded710c96e4f1336c9806638be0e3c3b138eedf] Upgrade to JUCE 5.2.0
git bisect skip 4ded710c96e4f1336c9806638be0e3c3b138eedf
# good: [5789b75125c8a722b57ca9f523ea311329393270] Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed
git bisect good 5789b75125c8a722b57ca9f523ea311329393270
# good: [4f4921f6ac33ef582e9736a8634d8f5c2350339e] Build files cleanup for JUCE 5.2.0 and Windows
git bisect good 4f4921f6ac33ef582e9736a8634d8f5c2350339e
# bad: [501994b18bacd39f38a8d6c67ac9ce8cc630f2ea] Pitchbend now listen to all channel. Fix #100 First implementation of the standalone version
git bisect bad 501994b18bacd39f38a8d6c67ac9ce8cc630f2ea
# first bad commit: [501994b18bacd39f38a8d6c67ac9ce8cc630f2ea] Pitchbend now listen to all channel. Fix #100 First implementation of the standalone version
```

So it seems that something bad was introduced in commit 501994b18bacd39f38a8d6c67ac9ce8cc630f2ea.

items.title: JACK support for standalone version?
items.body:
Is there an option to build the standalone version with JACK audio output and MIDI input support?

items.title: macOS window placement & movement issue (and solution): standalone version
items.body:
in macOS you can drag windows around by all edges, so it is common for some of us to move windows 95% or more off the desktop to temporarily clean up some space. With dexed, I noticed (only happened once and am trying to recreate it, you can drag it off so far that you can't drag it back on, because you can't get to a dragable part of the window. The only dragable part is the top menu bar, unlike other windows that have a dragable location at all points. 

If this happens (at least in OSX 10.12), you can go into System Preferences > Displays > Resolution and set the resolution to scaled and choose an option that brings the dexed window back into the desktop more, and from there move it around until it stays where you want it. Took me a while to figure this out.

At some point when working on the macOS window components, it might be good to add dragable edges, but for the moment, this work.

Really enjoying having dexed. Today I'll try to hook it up to my TX81Z and see if I can up/down load anything.

items.title: sending sysex voice bulk data to Dexed results in operators being "randomly" turned on and off
items.body: I was experimenting with using Dexed as the target of an external editor. I discovered that sending voice data to Dexed caused operators to randomly turn on and off. Turns out that the checksum byte (data byte 155) was being used for this (parameter change 155 (group = 0, subgroup = 1, parameter = 27) handles this, but that data isn't included in a bulk dump.

items.title: Standalone: missing sysex menus doesn't eliminate communication

bool SysexComm::setInput(juce::String) sysex Netzwerk FS1R_Netz opened
bool SysexComm::setOutput(juce::String) sysex Netzwerk FS1R_Netz opened


So it appears that it's still opening those ports, probably that should be disabled if you really want to eliminate the feature.

items.title: Cleanup + Envelopes
items.body: The first three commits are just cleanup + JUCE update. The final commit addresses an omission in the Dexed implementation of the DX7 envelope. If L(N) == L(N+1), the previous implementation would not properly hold for some time determined by R. I've measured the hold time on my TX816 and approximated those values (rounded off a bit), and it works pretty well. Could use a second pair of eyes and ears, and maybe you have some concerns or other ideas about how to approach this.

items.title: LFO: Amplitude modulation not working
items.body: In the latest code, AMD appears to have no effect. PMD is working fine.

items.title: memory leaks, compiler warnings and the DX7 envelope
items.body: Here are a few commits you might like to have. In particular the DX7 envelope rate fix could use a second pair of eyes, but it appears to be doing the right thing.

items.title: Envelope bug
items.body:
There's a bug with Dexed's envelopes when the level of the current stage == level of the next stage. In that case, rate will be ignored and the envelope will immediately advance to the following stage. Which breaks a patch like the attached (operator 1 & 3 should be offset in time, but sound together). 

[DreamPiano.syx.zip](https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed/files/1707231/DreamPiano.syx.zip)

items.title: Clips in sound when Dexed is set in mono
items.body:
Hello, I would like to report an error.
Maybe it's already been reported before ... I hope it's not like that.

The error is that some clips are produced when the instrument sounds in MONO.
In this link you can find a MIDI file to use in a DAW and put DEXED in MONO with some instrument.
Changing notes sometimes produce clips, creaks in the sound.

[https://www.dropbox.com/s/5w3bdwuxfwhl828/dexedClipsInMono.mid?dl=0](url)

items.title: 24 engine ignores  feedback operator in algo  6
items.body:
This bug concerns algo 5 and 6 , differences between engine type ( mark 1 versus modern ) .

Algoritm 5 : only operator 6 is feedback enabled .
Algoritm 6: is output of carrier 5 back to modulator 6 which in turns goes into 5 ..thus both operators are part of the feedback loop 

Both algorimts have a different character when feedback is enabled ..
Now the bug .


The bug is when dexed is set to 24 bit engine option , algoritm 6 is treated the same as algoritm 5 ., you can clearly hear this when switching algoritms , engine type .
In 24 bit algo 6 , is completely ignoring the feedback going from 5 back --> 6

The engine settings should have no effect on the algoritm settings ., recreating both algo's in an fm synth like fm7/fm8 or sytrus ...both algoritms have different character . 

And this should be the case with dexed too when switching engines .
On the dexed site , the creator states that the engine type also has an influence on the bit depth of the sine waves and the amplitude scales , this should be no reason why the modern engine ignores a feedback opera-tor .
Other F.M. synths do it correctly

Link to sound file 
https://app.box.com/s/qk248k3llx8cbqu8ommuwn9zmoysc0ij
And link to screenshot of algo 6

items.title: DexedTheme.xml Colors are Inconsistent + Background Glitch + Documentation Typo
items.body:
I'm trying to create a new theme for Dexed using DexedTheme.xml but I'm encountering these problems:

Colors turn grey, seemingly always #7F7F7F, when the alpha is set above 7F. It also seems to never be fully opaque with the preset window always being translucent and the background displaying echoes / repeated images of the UI that change as I mouse over and interact with elements, spotted with the normal UI images and checked with 1px transparent PNGs to uncover more of the background.

I'm using the format value="0x7FFF0000" understood to be Alpha, Red, Green, Blue, though the Documentation in DexedTheme.md says it's Alpha Red Blue Green but that isn't documented on Juce's website. For me this turns #FF0000 into #FE0000 or #7F0000 with all the images swapped out for transparent PNGs so I can be sure it's not being affected by drop-shadows or anything.

items.title: All Notes Off / All Sound Off
items.body:
Hello, Thanks for Dexed, it's amazing! I think the "All Notes Off" (CC=123/0x7B) handling is odd? It behaves more like "All Sound Off" (ie. CC=120/0x78) ? Some keyboards (ie, from Roland, ie the D-50) send "All Notes Off" messages whenever the last remaining held key is released (ie. very often).  This change makes Dexed unplayable from these instruments.  Could L308 below be changed from 123 to 120? The logic for 123 is a little more involved I guess, it should release any open notes in the "usual" way.  The description at the midi-cc-list table below is I think quite clear about this. Best, rd

- https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed/issues/72
- https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed/blob/master/Source/PluginProcessor.cpp#L308
- http://nickfever.com/music/midi-cc-list

MIDI CC120 | All Sound Off | Mutes all sounding notes. It does so regardless of release time or sustain. 

MIDI CC123 | All Notes Off | Mutes all sounding notes. Release time will still be maintained, and notes held by sustain will not turn off until sustain pedal is depressed.

items.title: Inconsistent parameter typing prevents compilation (sometimes)
items.body:
I found the following inconsistencies between parameter types that prevent the code to be compiled without modifications:

1. EngineMKI::render fails to "override" FmCore::render because of last parameter
```
EngineMkI.h   void EngineMkI::render(int32_t*, FmOpParams*, int, int32_t*, int) override;
FmCore.h	  void FmCore::render(int32_t*, FmOpParams*, int, int32_t*, int32_t)
```

2. Env fails to compile because of second-to-last parameters of Env::init and Env::update.
```
env.h      void Env::init(const int*, const int*, int,     int)
env.cpp    void Env::init(const int*, const int*, int32_t, int)

env.h      void Env::update(const int*, const int*, int,     int)
env.cpp    void Env::update(const int*, const int*, int32_t, int)
```

It appears that int is not always the same as int32_t :-)

Ralph

items.title: Pitch EG - can't get it to be quick enough
items.body:
When trying to make drum sounds with Dexed, I that the Pitch EG creates a rather slow pitch ramp even when I'm using the fastest possible Rate values for the controls points.

I'd expect just a click, but this makes a long pitch slide instead:
![selection_064](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/491704/31679788-87db2f4a-b372-11e7-8fad-7047e0c4bd53.png)

I can't get a fast pitch ramp with this, which is strange becaue other EGs allow me to make short AD type bursts.

Am I doing something wrong? Or maybe DX7 worked this way and it's meant to be like that?

items.title: good but non-original 'OP on/off' behavior?
items.body:
In Dexed, the 'OP output levels' are computed for every note-on which is also how the original dx7 worked. In other words when a key is pressed down, changing the OP output levels doesn't affect the sound, until you replay the note or add a few notes (in which case the added notes will have the new output level and the first held note still has the 'old' output level'.

I don't have a dx7 but on my TX816 the OP on/off buttons work in the same way. They only affect the sound for new notes played after the on/off buttons were changed. If I hold a note and change these buttons the sound is not affected. 

In Dexed however the sound changes immediately, which is in fact a good thing (=direct feedback). But because the output level knobs work the same way as the original DX7/TX816 I thought it might be overlooked that the OP on/off buttons work in the same way..AT LEAST ON MY TX816. Could be that is worked differently on the DX7, but I don't think so as the TX816 came out two years later and still has this 'vintage' parameter change behavior.

that's all :)

items.title: The option "send current program to DX7" always sent to the DX7 midi channel 1
items.body: I use the the option "send current program to DX7"  (right click on the near the DEXED logo) or the option "send program 'xxx ' to dx7 " from the cart screen. The two options are sending to the DX7 channel 1 only. The DX7 channel specified in the PARM screen is ignored.

items.title: Dexed sounds mono(not Stereo) issue
items.body: I've download dexed and placed in Vst folder for DAW. It worked with Cubase 8.5 however, it sounds mono on every patch. I've already checked the out put channel of the Vst instrument track, compared with another Vsti and there was no problem. What should I do for solving this issue?

items.title: Can't install on osx 10.12 and Ableton Live 9
items.body:
I downloaded and unzipped the folder, moved the contents into Library>Audio>Plug-ins where everyone else lives, rescanned for plug-ins in Ableton, quit, restarted multiple times, tried in the 32 bit version. No dice, it doesn't show up in the VST or AU folder in Ableton.

Any ideas? Would really appreciate some direction here. 

Thanks!!!!!

items.title: dexed does not send midi data when loading new patch in ableton
items.body:
firstly just wanted to say that dexed is amazing!

i have set up macros for operator levels with dexed vst in ableton live.  i can control all the operator levels with the macro knobs on a push2. that works fine.

but when i load a new patch, dexed doesnt send the new operator level midi data. this means the macros show the operator levels of the previous patch, not the new currently loaded patch.

expected behaviour would be that upon loading of the new patch, dexed sends new midi data for all automatable parameters to the host DAW.  with the current behaviour it makes it very difficult to use an external controller with dexed.

items.title: Dexed Not Showing in Ableton 32bit PC
items.body:
Hi, I have been trying get Dexed to work in Ableton 32bit for PC. Have tried about three different versions of the plugin, but it just won't show in my plugin folder.

Any help would be most appreciated, as really want to give Dexed a try.

Thanks in advance.

items.title: Parameter edit on the DX7 is not received
items.body: I've noticed that SysEx messages are sent from the plugin if I move a parameter and updated correctly on the DX7 but not the other way around,  but sending an entire patch to Dexed via SysEx works, so probably it was meant to work in this way but I think that it should be useful to have a bidirectional update of parameters between the plugin and the DX7. It could be doable?

items.title: Source/PluginProcessor.cpp compile error
items.body:
`Compiling PluginProcessor.cpp
../../Source/PluginProcessor.cpp: In functie ‘void dexed_trace(const char*, const char*, ...)’:
../../Source/PluginProcessor.cpp:639:25: fout: ‘va_start’ was not declared in this scope
     va_start(argptr, fmt);
                         ^
../../Source/PluginProcessor.cpp:641:18: fout: ‘va_end’ was not declared in this scope
     va_end(argptr);
`

I was able to fix it by adding

`#include "stdarg.h"`

After this compilation was succesful.
I am on Linux Fedora 25 64bits, using gcc 6.3.1

items.title: use native log2 and round in vs2013+
items.body: vs2013+ support C99 **round** and **log2** functions, so let's get rid of warning

items.title: need more clear indication of operator on/off
items.body: operator on/off switch is low contrast,difficult to see its state.please increase shading contrast or maybe make operator name(number) greyed if turned off.another idea is to turn off red indicator above ratio/fixed or grey the operator in algorithm display panel.thankyou.

When I click STORE > EXTERNAL FILE > and choose a cartridge I get the above error message.

I recently downloaded and installed the newest version of dexed and i think this may have something to do with.

Any help appreciated!

items.title: Detune doesn't work like a DX7
items.body:
Detune is currently implemented as a fixed Hertz increment.  When looking at dx7note.cc, I see the following comment:  "This was measured at 7.213Hz per count at 9600Hz, but the exact value is somewhat dependent on midinote. Close enough for now."

On patches that use detune strategically, this causes detune-based chorusing type effects to be the wrong speed as you move around the keyboard and is a noticeable difference between Dexed and a real DX7.  For reference, watch this video where it is apparent:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FjsJeybu85I   (I didn't make the video, but it did bring this issue to my attention.)

The correct behavior is to detune by cents instead of Hertz.  (ie, the detune amount is relative to the note pitch and not a fixed amount.)

According to the DX7II manual, the range is +/- 2 cents.  So a detune of -7 is -2 cents and a detune of +7 is +2 cents.  I do not know how the values between +/- 1-7 are mapped to the +/- 0-2 cent range and would have to measure a real instrument to determine it, but even a linear interpolation between values would be much better than the current fixed frequency approximation.

Your noted measurement in the comment suggests that the original DX7 might have a different, wider, detuning range than the stated range for a DX7II if I'm understanding it correctly.  (2 cents is a 1.001156 frequency ratio, which would be about +/- 11 Hz at 9600 Hz)  (Those values are based upon the pitch conversion tools here:  http://www.sengpielaudio.com/calculator-centsratio.htm )

It seems to me that improving the implementation of operator detune would be an important change to make for at least the Mark I engine.
